ENTITYNAME: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, ('CIBC')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ('SEC')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On December 22, 2003 the SEC filed a Complaint with the US District Court for the Southern District of Texas alleging that CIBC aided and abetted violations of the federal securities laws related to certain structured finance transactions between CIBC and the Enron Corporation including Enron's manipulation of its reported financial results through a series of financial transactions that were improperly reported by Enron as asset sales; that CIBC knew or was reckless in not knowing that loans were structured as asset sales for accounting and financial reporting purposes and therefore CIBC knowingly and substantially assisted Enron to file with the SEC false and misleading reports and failed to make and keep accurate books, records and accounts. Without admitting or denying any wrongdoing CIBC consented to the entry of a Final Judgment permanently enjoining CIBC from violation of Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule l0b-5 there under, Section 13(a) of the Exchange Act and Rules 12b-20, 13a-1 and 13a-13 there under, Section 13(b)(2) of the Exchange Act, Rule 13b2-1, and Section 13(b)(5) of the Exchange Act. This Final Judgment was also filed on December 22, 2003. On the same day CIBC deposited with the Court $80,000,000 in disgorgement, interest and a civil penalty. In addition to these sanctions CIBC also agreed that it will not seek any benefit from any offset or reduction of any investor's claim, and that it shall not seek reimbursement or indemnification, nor any tax deduction or credit for any of the amount paid. The SEC has agreed to not institute any proceedings against CIBC, its subsidiaries or affiliates pursuant to Sections 15(b), 15B, 15C, or 19(h) of the Exchange Act.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final judgment as outlined in (v) above

ENTITYNAME: CIBC World Markets Corp and Canadian Imperial Holdings Inc.
ACTIONTITLE: In the Matter of Canadian Imperial Holding Inc. and CIBC World Markets Corp.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: SEC and the Attorney General for the State of New York
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On July 20, 2005 Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce ('CIBC') and The United States Securities and Exchange Commission (the 'SEC') announced a joint settlement (the 'Settlement') of certain of CIBC's U.S. subsidiaries with the SEC and the Attorney General for the State of New York ('NYAG') of proceedings in relation to the activities of the subsidiaries in respect of certain alleged mutual fund market timing practices. The CIBC subsidiaries to which the Settlement relates are CIBC World Markets Corp. ('World Markets'), Canadian Imperial Holdings Inc. ('CIHI'), CIBC Bank and Trust (Cayman) Limited, Rudy Capital USA LLC and Hudson River Investments LLC (the 'Other Parties'). On July 20, 2005, the SEC issued an Order Instituting Administrative and Cease-and-Desist Proceeding, Making Findings, and Imposing Remedial Sanctions and a Cease-and-Desist Order Pursuant to Section 8A of the Securities Act of 1933 (the 'Securities Act'), Sections 15(b) and 21C of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ('Exchange Act'), Section 203(e) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, and Sections 9(b) and 9(f) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 ('Investment Company Act') (the 'SEC Order'). Under the SEC Order: (a) Without CIHI admitting or denying such findings, the SEC found that as a result of World Markets' registered representatives' facilitation of market timing and related financial transactions in which CIHI participated, CIHI wilfully violated Section 17(a) of the Securities Act, Sections 7(d) and 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, Rule 22c-1, as adopted under Section 22(c) of the Investment Company Act and Regulation U promulgated by the Federal Reserve Board. (b) Without World Markets admitting or denying such findings, the SEC found that as a result of World Markets' registered representatives' facilitation of market timing and related financial transactions, World Markets wilfully violated Section 17(a) of the Securities Act, Sections 7(c), 10(b), 11(d), 15(c) and 17(a) of the Exchange Act and Rules 10b-3, 10b-5 and 17a-3 thereunder, Rule 22c-1, as adopted under Section 22(c) of the Investment Company Act and Regulation T promulgated by the Federal Reserve Board. (c) World Markets and CIHI agree to pay disgorgement and prejudgement interest in the amount of $100 million and a civil money penalty of $25 million (all numbers in U.S. dollars), and to retain an independent distribution consultant to develop a plan for the distribution of the $125 million to investors. (d) CIHI agrees to cease and desist from committing or causing any violations of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act, Sections 7(d) and 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, Rule 22c-1 as adopted under Section 22(c) of the Investment Company Act and Regulation U promulgated by the Federal Reserve Board regarding the extension of margin credit. (e) World Markets agrees to cease and desist from committing or causing any violations of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act, Sections 7(c), 10(b), 11(d), 15(c) and 17(a) of the Exchange Act and Rules 10b-3, 10b-5 and 17a-3 thereunder, Rule 22c-1 as adopted under Section 22(c) of the Investment Company Act and Regulation T promulgated by the Federal Reserve Board regarding the extension of margin credit. The settlement with the NYAG (the 'NYAG Settlement') is effected under an Assurance of Discontinuance under which the NYAG will agree not to pursue an action against CIHI, World Markets and the Other Parties. The NYAG Settlement requires CIHI, World Markets and the Other Parties to make payment of the $125 million arising under the SEC Order.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Agreement of settlement as detailed in (v) above

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that from at least January 1, 2003 through June 30, 2004, in connection with certain auctions, the Bank of New York Mellon (formerly, The Bank of New York, 'BNY') accepted initial or revised bids after submission deadlines and allowed broker-dealers to intervene in auctions. In certain instances, this conduct also affected the rate paid on the auction rate securities. As a result, BNY caused violations of section 17(a)(2) of the Securities Act. BNY was required to make certain disclosures regarding its material auction practices and procedures; and not later than 6 months after the date of this order, unless otherwise extended by the Staff of the Commission for good cause shown, have its CEO or general counsel certify in writing to the Staff of the Commission that BNY has implemented procedures. In addition BNY paid a monetary settlement in the amount of $750,000.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10 (c) (2) (vi) above

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Attorney for EDNY and SDNY
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Bank of New York Mellon (formerly, The Bank of New York, the 'Bank'), an affiliate of the registrant, entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorneys offices for the Eastern and Southern Districts of New York ('EDNY' and 'SDNY'). The respective EDNY and SDNY investigations related to actions by Bank employees that facilitated a fraudulent scheme conducted by RW Professional Leasing Services Corp., a former customer of one of the Bank's Long Island branch offices, and certain funds transfer activities to and from Russia from 1996 to 1999. Among other things, the non-prosecution agreement outlines a series of measures, many of which already are completed and others that are well underway, to enhance the Bank's procedures for monitoring and reporting suspicious activity. The Bank has agreed to pay restitution and forfeiture totalling $38 million, all of which has been previously reserved. The agreement, which has a term of three years, provides for the Bank to retain an independent examiner to review the enhanced procedures and report to the government on a periodic basis.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10 (d)(2)(v) above

ENTITYNAME: Dreyfus Service Organization, Inc.
ACTIONTITLE: Proceeding by the Commissioner of Banking and Ins. State of NJ Ref. No. 8059711
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, Trenton, New Jersey
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: It was alleged that Dreyfus Service Organization ('DSO') between June 2002 and November 2002 'caused, permitted or was otherwise responsible for allowing the employee to solicit and write eight New Jersey annuity contracts without the benefit of a current license.' DSO had an employee with a non-resident NJ insurance license which had expired and was later reinstated. The sales were made during the period when the employee's license was inactive, although DSO had reason to believe the license was, in fact, active. Without admitting or denying any violation of the insurance statutes or regulations or any wrongdoing, DSO consented to an administrative sanction in the amount of $4,000.00 to fully and completely resolve the matter.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(d)(4)(v) above.

ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On March 14, 2001, the FSA entered an order against CIBC Japan suspending the business of its Financial Products Department from March 26, 2001 to March 30, 2001, suspending its business of acting as an intermediary in derivatives transactions and sale of monetary claims from March 26, 2001 to March 30, 2001, and requiring a submission of a Remedial Action Plan for implementation of a stronger internal control/compliance system, as a result of the FSA's findings that CIBC Japan violated the Japanese Securities and Exchange Law by conducting a Financial Products and Derivatives business for which it was not licensed and permitting the conduct of related sales activities by unregistered securities representatives.

ENTITYNAME: CIBC Mellon Trust Company
ACTIONTITLE: Securities and Exchange Commission v. CIBC Mellon Trust Company
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ('SEC')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: CIBC Mellon Trust Company ('CMTC') submitted a Consent to Entry of Judgment (the 'Consent') which was presented by the SEC in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia (the 'Court') on February 16, 2005. In the Consent, and solely for the purpose of the injunctive action and any other proceedings arising out of the SEC's investigation brought by or on behalf of the SEC or to which the SEC is a party, CMTC consented to the entry of Final Judgment as to Defendant CMTC (the 'Final Judgment') without admitting or denying the matters set forth therein (other than those relating to the jurisdiction of the Court and the subject matter of the action). The Final Judgment, entered on February 24, 2005, resolved the allegations that CMTC had failed to register as a transfer agent with the SEC, that it had issued 'legend free' stock certificates of a company whose shares were not registered with the SEC, that one of its managers had accepted payments of stock from that company's officers to issue the certificates, and that it had acted as an unregistered broker or dealer in connection with its stock plan administration business. CMTC was permanently enjoined from prescribed violations of Securities Act Section 5, Exchange Act Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5, Exchange Act Section 15(a), Exchange Act Section 17A(c)(1), and from aiding and abetting future violations of Exchange Act Section 10(b) or Rule 10b-5. CMTC also agreed to pay a civil monetary penalty of $5 million and disgorgement of $889,773 and prejudgment interest of $140,270. Payment was made on March 4, 2005. CMTC also consented, without admitting or denying the SEC complaint's allegations, to the entry of an SEC administrative order based on the Final Judgment on March 2, 2005 (the 'Order'). Pursuant to the Order, CMTC was censured and agreed to an undertaking to engage an independent consultant to review its relevant businesses and procedures. This matter responds to items 10B(1) and 10C(2).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Entry of Judgment on consent. See item (v) above for detail.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that the Bank of New York Mellon(formerly, The Bank of New York, 'BNY') failed as a transfer agent to exercise reasonable care to ascertain the correct addresses of lost security holders and escheated assets belonging to those security holders to various states. As a result BNY entered into agreement to offer payment to certain security holders for property escheated erroneously (while reserving the right to pursue their claim for repayment with the State to which the property was escheated). In addition BNY paid a penalty of $250,000 and agreed to the retention of an independent consultant to review and evaluate certain of the Bank's policies and procedures.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10 (c) (2) (vi) above

ENTITYNAME: CIBC World Markets Inc. ('CIBC World Markets')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Ontario & Quebec Securities Commissions, Canada
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On February 12, 2003 each Commission approved a Settlement Agreement between CIBC World Markets and itself, whereby CIBC World Markets agreed to submit to a review of its practices relating to the disclosure of potential conflicts of interest in its equities research reports and institute changes ordered by the Commissions; to be reprimanded by the Commissions; and to pay $100,000 towards the costs of the Commissions' investigations. The Settlement Agreements were negotiated in relation to proceedings initiated by the Commissions as a result of CIBC World Markets violating Ontario and Quebec securities law by failing to adequately disclose the potential conflicts of interest inherent in recommendations it made, within five research reports, to purchase the shares of Shoppers Drug Mart Corporation ('Shoppers'). Specifically, the reports failed to adequately disclose that (i) CIBC World Markets had assumed an underwriting liability to Shoppers in the 12 months prior to the reports; (ii) CIBC World Markets, along with its affiliate, owned 7,450,000 shares of Shoppers; and (iii) Shoppers was indebted to CIBC (CIBC World Markets' parent corporation).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The Commissions approved a Settlement Agreement as specified in (v) above.

ENTITYNAME: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Tokyo Branch
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Financial Services Agency, Japan (FSA)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: In an action related to the first item listed above under 10(f), on April 13, 2001, the FSA entered an order against the CIBC Branch suspending all business of the Equities Derivatives Department from April 23, 2001 to April 27, 2001 and requiring submission of a Remedial Action Plan to the FSA, as a result of the FSA's findings that the CIBC Branch violated the Japanese Banking Law and the Securities and Exchange Law by: (i) structuring/executing a Single Stock Option Linked Swap, (ii) structuring/executing a Nikkei Stock Index Linked Swap, (iii) structuring/executing inappropriate transactions which could be used for the intentional manipulation of accounting by customers, (iv) improperly handling conflict of interest/ information management due to the commingled business operations of CIBC Japan, the CIBC Branch and a service company in Japan, (v) poorly managing market, liquidity, operational and system risk, and (vi) insufficiently following up on observations made by CIBC's Internal Audit Department.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: FSA entered order as specified in (v) above.

ENTITYNAME: CIBC World Markets Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Market Regulation Services Inc., Toronto, Canada
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Market Regulation Services Inc. ('RS') alleged that in 2002, a group of related clients with accounts at CIBC World Markets Inc. ('CIBC WM') engaged in suspicious trading in certain stocks and warrants listed on the TSX and the TSX Venture Exchanges, which had the appearance of manipulative and deceptive trading. The trading was carried out through numerous accounts held by the client group, including retail accounts and individual RRSP accounts and Direct Market Access trading accounts at CIBC Investor Services Inc. ('CIBC ISI'), CIBC WM and another unrelated investment dealer. It was alleged that CIBC WM did not fulfill its trading supervision obligations in relation to the client. On December 21, 2004, RS approved a settlement agreement with CIBC WM pursuant to which CIBC WM admitted that: CIBC WM failed to comply with its trading supervision obligations, contrary to Section 2-401(5) of the Rules of the Toronto Stock Exchange; and, in the period of April to December 2002, CIBC WM failed to comply with its trading supervision obligations, contrary to Universal Market Integrity Rule 7.1 (1) and Policy 7.1. As part of the Settlement Agreement CIBC WM was required to pay to RS a fine of $700,000 and $92,500 towards RS' investigation costs. CIBC WM also agreed to implement specified measures, by June 30, 2005, to ensure compliance with its obligations going forward.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: December 21, 2004 Settlement Agreement as outlined in (v) above.

ENTITYNAME: BANK OF AMERICA, N.A.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: ON MAY 4, 1998, THE U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION ALLEGED IN AN ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDING (FILE NO. 3-9596) THAT NATIONSBANK, N.A. (NATIONSBANK), THE PREDECESSOR OF THE CORPORATE PARENT OF THE APPLICANT, WAS A CAUSE OF VIOLATIONS OF SECTION 17(A)(2) AND (3) OF THE SECURITIES ACT OF 1933 BY NATIONSSECURITIES IN CONNECTION WITH THE INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING OF SHARES OF NATIONS GOVERNMENT INCOME TERM TRUST 2003, INC. AND NATIONS GOVERNMENT INCOME TERM TRUST 2004, INC. (NATIONSSECURITIES IS THE PREDECESSOR TO BANC OF AMERICA INVESTMENT SERVICES, INC., A REGISTERED BROKER-DEALER AND REGISTERED INVESTMENT ADVISER AND A RELATED PERSON OF THE APPLICANT.) ON THE SAME DATE, WITHOUT ADMITTING OR DENYING THE ALLEGATIONS, NATIONSBANK CONSENTED TO AN ORDER TO CEASE AND DESIST FROM COMMITTING OR CAUSING VIOLATIONS OF SECTION 17(A)(2) AND (3) OF THE SECURITIES ACT OF 1933.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT DISTRIBUTORS, INC.; COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT ADVISORS, INC.; BANC OF AMERICA CAPITAL MANAGEMENT, LLC; BACAP DISTRIBUTORS, LLC
ACTIONTITLE: COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT DISTRIBUTORS, INC.; COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT ADVISORS, INC.; BANC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: THE BACAP, BACAP DISTRIBUTORS, CMA and CFDI SEC ORDERS REQUIRE BACAP, BACAP DISTRIBUTORS, CMA AND CFDI TO: (I) MAINTAIN A COMPLIANCE AND ETHICS OVERSIGHT INFRASTRUCTURE HAVING, AMONG OTHER ELEMENTS, A CODE OF ETHICS OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE, AN INTERNAL COMPLIANCE CONTROLS COMMITTEE, A SENIOR LEVEL COMPLIANCE OFFICER FOR CONFLICTS OF INTEREST, AND A CORPORATE OMBUDSMAN; (II) RETAIN INDEPENDENT COMPLIANCE CONSULTANTS TO, AMONG OTHER THINGS, REVIEW CMA AND CFDI COMPLIANCE, SUPERVISORY, AND OTHER POLICIES AND PROCEDURES, AND ADOPT THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF SUCH CONSULTANTS; AND (III) UNDERGO INDEPENDENT THIRD PARTY COMPLIANCE REVIEW EVERY OTHER YEAR AND RETAIN AN INDEPENDENT DISTRIBUTION CONSULTANT. IN ADDITION, BAS SHALL MAINTAIN A COMPLIANCE AND ETHICS OVERSIGHT INFRASTRUCTURE HAVING, AMONG OTHER THINGS, A CODE OF ETHICS OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE, AN INTERNAL COMPLIANCE CONTROLS COMMITTEE AND A CORPORATE OMBUDSMAN. BAS SHALL ALSO UNDERGO INDEPENDENT THIRD PARTY COMPLIANCE REVIEW EVERY OTHER YEAR AND RETAIN AN INDEPENDENT DISTRIBUTION CONSULTANT. MOREOVER, CMA AND BACAP AGREED NOT TO MANAGE OR ADVISE THE COLUMBIA FUNDS, INCLUDING FORMER NATIONS FUNDS, UNLESS THE COLUMBIA FUNDS IMPLEMENT CERTAIN CORPORATE GOVERNANCE PRACTICES, INCLUDING THAT CERTAIN TRUSTEES OF THE NATIONS FUNDS NOT STAND FOR REELECTION, HAVING 75% OF TRUSTEES MEET INDEPENDENCE STANDARDS, HAVING CHAIRMEN BE INDEPENDENT, APPOINTING A SENIOR OFFICER AND ONE OR MORE INDEPENDENT CONSULTANTS TO, AMONG OTHER THINGS, MONITOR COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL AND STATE SECURITIES LAWS, STATE LAWS RESPECTING CONFLICTS OF INTEREST, FIDUCIARY DUTIES AND CODES OF ETHICS AND COMPLIANCE POLICIES AND MANAGE THE PROCESS BY WHICH PROPOSED MANAGEMENT FEES TO BE CHARGED TO THE COLUMBIA FUNDS ARE NEGOTIATED. FINALLY, CMA AND BACAP AGREED TO DEVELOP PROCEDURES FOR THE DISCLOSURE OF FEES AND COSTS, INCLUDING PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF A SUMMARY OF ANY ANNUAL INDEPENDENT WRITTEN EVALUATION OF THESE FEES.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BANK OF AMERICA, N.A.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: OFFICE OF THE COMPTROLLER OF THE CURRENCY
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: ON MAY 4, 1998, THE OFFICE OF THE COMPTROLLER OF THE CURRENCY (OCC) FOUND THAT NATIONSBANK, N.A. (NATIONSBANK), THE PREDECESSOR OF THE CORPORATE PARENT OF THE APPLICANT, FAILED TO ADHERE TO A CONDITION IN THE OCC'S LETTER APPROVING NATIONSSECURITIES PARTNERSHIP WITH DEAN WITTER AND VIOLATED A CONDITION IN AN OCC BANKING CIRCULAR WHICH PROVIDED GUIDANCE TO ALL NATIONAL BANKS WITH RESPECT TO THE SALE AND MARKETING OF INVESTMENT PRODUCTS ON BANK PREMISES, IN ASSOCIATION WITH THE INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING OF SHARES OF THE NATIONS GOVERNMENT INCOME TERM TRUST 2003, INC. AND NATIONS GOVERNMENT INCOME TERM TRUST 2004, INC. ON THE SAME DATE, WITHOUT ADMITTING OR DENYING THE ALLEGATIONS, CHARGES OR FINDINGS, NATIONSBANK CONSENTED TO PAY A CIVIL MONETARY PENALTY OF $750,000.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT ADVISORS, INC.; COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT DISTRIBUTORS, INC.; BANC OF AMERICA CAPITAL MANAGEMENT, LLC;BACAP DISTRIBUTORS, LLC
ACTIONTITLE: COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT ADVISORS, INC.; COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT DISTRIBUTORS, INC.; BANC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: OFFICE OF THE NEW YORK ATTORNEY GENERAL ('NYAG')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: THE NYAG ASSURANCE OF DISCONTINUANCE PROVIDES THAT (1) BACAP AND BACAP DISTRIBUTORS AGREE, WITH AFFILIATE COLUMBIA MANAGEMENT ADVISORS, INC. (CMA), TO REDUCE MANAGEMENT FEES CHARGED TO CERTAIN NATIONS AND COLUMBIA FUNDS DISTRIBUTED TO RETAIL INVESTORS BY $32 MILLION PER YEAR THROUGH 2009, FOR A TOTAL OF $160 MILLION IN FEE REDUCTIONS; (2) BACAP AGREES NOT TO MANAGE OR ADVISE THE NATIONS FUNDS UNLESS THE NATIONS FUNDS IMPLEMENT CERTAIN CHANGES IN CORPORATE GOVERNANCE PRACTICES, INCLUDING HAVING CHAIRMEN BE INDEPENDENT, HAVING 75% OF TRUSTEES MEET INDEPENDENCE STANDARDS, APPOINTING A SENIOR OFFICER WHO MEETS INDEPENDENCE STANDARDS TO, AMONG OTHER THINGS, MONITOR COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL AND STATE SECURITIES LAWS, STATE LAWS RESPECTING CONFLICTS OF INTEREST, FIDUCIARY DUTIES AND CODES OF ETHICS AND COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS AND MANAGE THE NEGOTIATION PROCESS FOR MANAGEMENT FEES; (3) BACAP AGREES TO DEVELOP PROCEDURES FOR THE DISCLOSURE OF FEES AND COSTS; AND (4) BACAP AND BACAP DISTRIBUTORS, WITH BAS, AGREE TO PAY, ON A JOINT AND SEVERAL BASIS, $250 MILLION IN DISGORGEMENT PLUS A CIVIL MONEY PENALTY OF $125 MILLION.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BANK OF AMERICA CORPORATION (BAC)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NEW YORK COUNTY (NEW YORK) DISTRICT ATTORNEY
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: BAC ENTERED INTO A CIVIL SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT WITH THE NEW YORK COUNTY (NEW YORK) DISTRICT ATTORNEY (DA) ON SEPTEMBER 28, 2006. THE AGREEMENT PROVIDES THAT, FROM ABOUT 2002 TO 2004, BAC HAD DEFICIENCIES IN CERTAIN INTERNAL ANTI-MONEY LAUNDERING CONTROLS AND FAILED TO REACT APPROPRIATELY TO THE RISK PRESENTED BY CERTAIN SOUTH AMERICAN MONEY SERVICES BUSINESS CUSTOMERS, WHO MOVED FUNDS ILLEGALLY THROUGH BAC. THE AGREEMENT REQUIRES BAC TO MAKE A TOTAL PAYMENT OF $7.5 MILLION, TO COOPERATE WITH THE DA IN ONGOING INVESTIGATIONS, AND TO ABIDE BY ANTI-MONEY LAUNDERING CHANGES RECOMMENDED BY BAC'S REGULATORS.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BANK OF AMERICA CORPORATION
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF RICHMOND
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: THE BANK AGREED TO CONTINUE TO TAKE STEPS TO ADOPT AND IMPLEMENT CORRECTIVE ACTIONS AND BEST PRACTICE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE INDEPENDENT CONSULTANTS AND TO ENHANCE THE ENTERPRISE-WIDE COMPLIANCE PROGRAM TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE LAWS AND REGULATIONS, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO SECURITIES LAWS AND REGULATIONS INCLUDING, AMONG OTHER THINGS, A PROCESS FOR RESOLVING OR ESCALATING COMPLIANCE ISSUES, ONGOING TRAINING ON POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS AND REGULATIONS FOR CERTAIN STAFF OF THE BANK AND ITS SUBSIDIARIES, ENSURE PROCESSES FOR AN ENHANCED APPROVAL PROCESS FOR NEW CLIENTS, NEW OR UNIQUE INVESTMENT PRODUCTS, SERVICES OR TRANSACTIONS, AND MATERIAL CHANGES TO EXISTING PRODUCTS OR SERVICES, PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THOROUGH ASSESSMENT OF RISKS, POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE PRODUCTS, SERVICES AND ARRANGEMENTS ARE CONSISTENT WITH BUSINESS EXPERTISE, STRATEGY AND APPROVED RISK PROFILE, PROCEDURES FOR INTERNAL AUDIT, MECHANISMS FOR PERIODIC REVIEWS, MONITORING OF ENTERPRISE-WIDE ADOPTION AND EXECUTION OF NEW POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AND OTHER RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE INDEPENDENT CONSULTS, AND SUBMISSION OF PROGRESS REPORTS TO RESERVE BANK.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BANK OF AMERICA, NATIONAL ASSOCIATION
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: OFFICE OF THE COMPTROLLER OF THE CURRENCY
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: THE BANK HAS ENTERED INTO A SUPERVISORY WRITTEN AGREEMENT DATED FEBRUARY 9, 2005, WITH THE COMPTROLLER OF THE CURRENCY. UNDER THE TERMS OF THE WRITTEN AGREEMENT, THE BANK HAS SUBMITTED AN ACTION PLAN (the PLAN) THAT IT SHALL IMPLEMENT AND ADHERE TO UNTIL IT RECEIVES FURTHER WRITTEN NOTICE FROM THE COMPTROLLER. THE PLAN PROVIDES FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF CORPORATE GOVERNANCE AND INTERNAL CONTROL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR TRANSACTION DOCUMENTATION OF EACH SIGNIFICANT NEW CUSTOMER RELATIONSHIP, NEW OR UNIQUE PRODUCT OR SERVICE, OR ANY SIGNIFICANT CHANGE TO AN EXISTING CUSTOMER RELATIONSHIP, PRODUCT, SERVICE, OR BUSINESS PRACTICE RECOMMENDED FOR THE APPROVAL BY THE WEALTH AND INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT GROUP; POLICIES AND PROCEDURES GOVERNING THE APPROVAL AND RISK MANAGEMENT OF EACH SIGNIFICANT NEW CUSTOMER RELATIONSHIP, NEW OR UNIQUE PRODUCT OR SERVICE, OR ANY SIGNIFICANT CHANGE TO AN EXISTING CUSTOMER RELATIONSHIP, PRODUCT, SERVICE OR BUSINESS PRACTICE RECOMMENDED FOR APPROVAL BY THE WEALTH AND INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT GROUP; AND DEVELOPMENT OF AUDIT PROCEDURES TO PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE COVERAGE OF ACTIVITY INVOLVING THE WEALTH AND INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT BUSINESS.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: NB Holdings Corporation (fka U.S. Trust Coporation)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Federal Reserve Board
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Federal Reserve Board and the New York State Banking Department alleged violations and deficiencies relating to the lack of internal controls and procedures and inadequate compliance with the Bank Secrecy Act, and the failure to maintain accurate and complete books and records in connection with the operations and activities of the Strategic Trading Group of Unites States Trust Company of New York. On July 11, 2001, U.S. Trust Corporation and United States Trust Company of New York paid to the Federal Reserve Board a civil monetary penalty in the amount of $5 million and made a $5 million monetary payment to the State of New York. U.S. Trust Corporation and United States Trust Company of New York, without admitting to any allegations, consented on July, 12, 2001, to the issuance of the order to cease and desist and order of assessment of a civil money penalty and money payment issued upon consent in connection with the alleged violations and deficiencies relating to the lack of internal controls and procedures and inadequate compliance with the Bank Secrecy Act, and relating to the failure to maintain accurate and complete books and records in connection with the operations and activities of the Strategic Trading Group of United States Trust Company of New York. United States Trust Company of New York is a predecessor to untied States Trust Company, National Association.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BACAP DISTRIBUTORS, LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: FROM JANUARY 2001 TO FEBRUARY 2004, BAI AND BACAP FAILED TO PRESERVE FOR 3 YEARS ELECTRONIC MAIL COMMUNICATIONS (INCLUDING INTER-OFFICE MEMORANDA & COMMUNICATIONS) RECEIVED & SENT BY ITS ASSOCIATED PERSONS & EMPLOYEES RELATED TO ITS BUSINESS AS A BROKER OR DEALER AS REQUIRED BY RULE 17A-4. DURING THE SAME PERIOD, BAI FAILED TO KEEP IN ANY EASILY ACCESSIBLE PLACE FOR A PERIOD OF 5 YEARS, AND/OR TO PRESERVE IN AN APPROPRIATE OFFICE FOR A PERIOD OF 2 YEARS, TRUE, ACCURATE & CURRENT WRITTEN COMMUNICATIONS RELATING TO RECOMMENDATIONS MADE, ADVICE GIVEN OR PROPOSED TO BE GIVEN; RECEIPT, DISBURSEMENT OR DELIVERY OF FUNDS OR SECURITIES; AND THE PLACING OR EXECUTION OF ORDERS TO PURCHASE & SELL SECURITIES AS REQUIRED BY RULE 204-2. WITHIN 90 DAYS OF THIS ORDER, BAI and BACAP WILL COMPLETE A REVIEW OF THEIR PROCEDURES FOR PRESERVATION OF ELECTRONIC MAIL COMMUNICATIONS AND ESTABLISH SYSTEMS & PROCEDURES DESIGNED TO ACHIEVE COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS, REGULATIONS & RULES. PURSUANT TO SECTION 21C OF THE EXCHANGE ACT, BAI AND BACAP WILL CEASE AND DESIST FROM COMMITTING OR CAUSING VIOLATIONS OR FUTURE VIOLATIONS OF SECTION 17(A) OF THE EXCHANGE ACT AND RULE 17A-4 THEREUNDER. PURSUANT TO SECTION 203(K) OF THE ADVISERS ACT, BAI SHALL CEASE AND DESIST FROM COMMITTING OR CAUSING TO COMMIT VIOLATIONS and ANY FUTURE VIOLATIONS OF SECTION 204 OF THE ADVISERS ACT AND RULE 204-2 THEREUNDER. BAI and BACAP ARE CENSURED PURSUANT TO SECTION 15(B)(4) OF THE EXCHANGE ACT & BAI IS ALSO CENSURED PURSUANT TO SECTION 203(E) OF THE ADVISERS ACT. WITHIN 10 DAYS OF THIS ORDER, BAI WILL PAY A CIVIL MONETARY PENALTY OF $1,000,000 TO THE SEC AND BACAP WILL PAY $500,000 TO THE SEC.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BANK OF AMERICA, N.A.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: CHICAGO BOARD OF TRADE
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: WITHOUT ADMITTING OR DENYING ANY VIOLATION OF REGULATION 9B.16, BANK OF AMERICA, N.A. AGREED TO PAY A FINE OF $20,000 IN SETTLEMENT OF THIS MATTER.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BANK OF AMERICA, N.A.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: ON MAY 4, 1998, THE U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION ALLEGED IN AN ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDING (FILE NO. 3-9596) THAT NATIONSBANK, N.A. (NATIONSBANK), THE PREDECESSOR OF THE CORPORATE PARENT OF THE APPLICANT, WAS A CAUSE OF VIOLATIONS OF SECTION 17(A)(2) AND (3) OF THE SECURITIES ACT OF 1933 BY NATIONSSECURITIES IN CONNECTION WITH THE INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING OF SHARES OF NATIONS GOVERNMENT INCOME TERM TRUST 2003, INC. AND NATIONS GOVERNMENT INCOME TERM TRUST 2004, INC. (NATIONSSECURITIES IS THE PREDECESSOR TO BANC OF AMERICA INVESTMENT SERVICES, INC., A REGISTERED BROKER-DEALER AND REGISTERED INVESTMENT ADVISER AND A RELATED PERSON OF THE APPLICANT.) ON THE SAME DATE, WITHOUT ADMITTING OR DENYING THE ALLEGATIONS, NATIONSBANK CONSENTED TO AN ORDER TO CEASE AND DESIST FROM COMMITTING OR CAUSING VIOLATIONS OF SECTION 17(A)(2) AND (3) OF THE SECURITIES ACT OF 1933.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BANK OF AMERICA CORPORATION
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: ON JULY 30, 2001, THE COMMISSION FOUND THAT , IN 1997 AND 1998, BANKAMERICA CORPORATION (BANKAMERICA), PREDECESSOR OF THE CORPORATE PARENT OF THE APPLICANT, (I) INCORRECTLY ACCOUNTED FOR A FINANCIAL RELATIONSHIP, AND (II) MADE INADEQUATE DISCLOSURES RELATED TO RISK IN EXCHANGE ACT REPORT FILINGS WITH THE COMMISSION, IN CONNECTION WITH A BUSINESS ALLIANCE WITH D.E. SHAW SECURITIES GROUP, L.P. AND RELATED ENTITIES. ON THE SAME DATE, WITHOUT ADMITTING OR DENYING THE COMMISSION'S ALLEGATIONS, CHARGES OR FINDINGS, THE APPLICANT'S CORPORATE PARENT (BANK OF AMERICA CORPORATION) CONSENTED TO AN ENTRY OF AN ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER PROVIDING THAT IT CEASE AND DESIST FROM COMMITTING OR CAUSING ANY FUTURE VIOLATIONS OF THE EXCHANGE ACT ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING PROVISIONS CITED IN THE COMMISSION'S ALLEGATIONS.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Final

ENTITYNAME: BACAP DISTRIBUTORS, LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: FROM JANUARY 2001 TO FEBRUARY 2004, BAI AND BACAP FAILED TO PRESERVE FOR 3 YEARS ELECTRONIC MAIL COMMUNICATIONS (INCLUDING INTER-OFFICE MEMORANDA & COMMUNICATIONS) RECEIVED & SENT BY ITS ASSOCIATED PERSONS & EMPLOYEES RELATED TO ITS BUSINESS AS A BROKER OR DEALER AS REQUIRED BY RULE 17A-4. WITHIN 90 DAYS OF THIS ORDER, BAI and BACAP WILL COMPLETE A REVIEW OF THEIR PROCEDURES FOR PRESERVATION OF ELECTRONIC MAIL COMMUNICATIONS AND ESTABLISH SYSTEMS & PROCEDURES DESIGNED TO ACHIEVE COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS, REGULATIONS & RULES. BAI and BACAP ARE CENSURED PURSUANT TO SECTION 15(B)(4) OF THE EXCHANGE ACT & BAI IS ALSO CENSURED PURSUANT TO SECTION 203(E) OF THE ADVISERS ACT. ENTITYNAME: Putnam U.S. Holdings I, LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Department of Labor
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Department of Labor alleged that Putnam had inappropriately offered, as investment options under the plan, class A shares in certain Putnam mutual funds which carried 12B-1 fees which were paid to Putnam Retail Management Limited Partnership, an affiliate of Putnam, in violation of Sections 404(A)(1)(B)(1) and 406(B)(2) of the Employee Retirement Security Act (ERISA).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Civil Penalty of $27,000.00 and disgorgement/restitution.

ENTITYNAME: GWFS Equities, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Florida Division of Securities and Investor Protection
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Alleged failure to renew Florida branch office location within prescribed time while continuing to conduct business.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Stipulation and Consent Agreement resulting in Administrative Fine of $5,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: GRS Securities, Inc.(GRSSI)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Investment Dealers Association of Canada
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: GRSSI held the assets of client investment plans with a trust company that unknown to it, did not meet certain requirements of an acceptable securities location.  As such, the assets were not allowable assets for the purposes of regulatory capital requirements and, for a short period of time until the matter was rectified, GRSSI did not meet the IDA Capital adequacy requirements.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Settlement.  Monetary fine of $40,000.00 plus costs.

ENTITYNAME: Putnam Investment Management LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that Putnam violated sections 203(E)(6), 206(1), 206(2) and 204A of the Investment Advisors Act of 1940 and Rule 17j-1(c) under the Investment Company Act of 1940 in connection with the personal trading of employees who allegedly engaged in excessive short-term trading ('market-timing') of Putnam mutual funds and Putnam's failure to reasonably supervise such employees or to properly disclose such actions.  Four of the individuals allegedly traded in mutual funds over which they had investment authority.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Decision & Order of Offer of Settlement which included a monetary fine of $50,000,000.00, censure and  disgorgement/restitution.

ENTITYNAME: Putnam Investment Management, LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that Putnam violated section 206(2) of the Investment Advisors Act of 1940 and Section 34(b) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 in connection with Putnam's alleged failure to adequately disclose certain brokerage allocation practices.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Consent agreement involving monetary penalty of $4,000,000.00, censure, cease and desist order and disgorgement.

ENTITYNAME: Putnam Investment Management, LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that Putnam violated Section 205 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 in connection with the alleged receipt from a mutual fund of performance based fees that did not comply with that Section.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Censure remedial sanctions and a cease and desist order.

ENTITYNAME: Putnam Investment Management, LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that Putnam violated Section 19(A) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 and Rule 19A-1 in connection with alleged distributions to the shareholders of certain closed end funds which were partly funded from shareholder capital without written notice identifying the source of distributions as other than the fund's net income as required by Rule 19A-1.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Consent and monetary penalty of $350,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: Investors Group Financial Services, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Mutual Fund Dealers Association of Canada
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Alleged violation of By-Law 1 of Mutual Fund Dealers Association of Canada related to market timing by one institutional client in certain mutual funds sponsored by Investor Group.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Monetary fine of $2,650,000.00, restitution to investors and implementation of other procedures.

ENTITYNAME: I.G. Investment Management, Ltd.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Manitoba Securities Commission and Ontario Securities Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: This matter related to market timing activity of one institutional client trading in mutual funds managed by I.G. Investment Management, Ltd.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Settlement Agreement and disgorgement/restitution to investors.

ENTITYNAME: M.R. S. Securities Services, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Investment Dealers Association of Canada
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Violation of By-Law 17.24A -depositing business receipts into a bank account of a related company before transferring the funds to the member's own account, usually within a day. the related company was a registered loan and trust company, but not an 'acceptable institution', as defined by the joint regulatory financial questionnaire and report. As a result, the practice had an adverse effect on the member's risk-adjusted capital as defined by the regulatory report. Member also deposited client cash with the same related company. As there was no written custodial agreement in existence between the member and the related company, this practice also had an adverse effect on the member's risk-adjusted capital.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Settlement and monetary fine of $39,150 and costs.

ENTITYNAME: IPC Investment Corporation
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: New Brunswick Securities Commission - Canada
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Unregistered trading activity conducted by salesperson of an affiliated dealer of IPC.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Order to pay monetary fine of $14,400.00 and administrative costs.

ENTITYNAME: M.R.S. Trust Company (MRST)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Manitoba Securities Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Manitoba Securities Commission (MSC) and other unrelated mutual fund dealers and their sales representatives in a notice  of hearing and statement of allegations relating back to a pension fund and RSP scheme that facilitated the improper withdrawal of locked-in funds from various Manitoba-resident planholders' pension and registered plans.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Settlement Agreement.  Company made a voluntary payment of $35,000 to the Treasury of the Province of Manitoba.

ENTITYNAME: IPC Securities Corporation (IPCS)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Nova Scotia Securities Commission (NSSC)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation related to allowing an approved person to operate out of the Wolfville office prior to receiving an exemption request from the NSSC, violating general securities rule 22 (20 and the NSSC ruling dated 9/28/04. the ruling requires IPCS to notify the Director of the NSSC if it established an office in Nova Scotia.)
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Settlement. IPCS agreed to pay an administrative penalty of $10,000.00 and costs.

ENTITYNAME: IPC Securities Corporation  (IPC)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Investment Dealers Association of Canada (IDA)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Alleged (1) failure to maintain records of supervisory activity in accordance with IDA requirements concerning Head Office Account Supervision; (2) failure to establish, maintain and/or enforce written policies and procedures to supervise principal trading done on behalf; and (3) failure to maintain its risk adjusted capital at a level greater than zero calculated in accordance with IDA Form 1.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Monetary fine in the amount of $100,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: Investors Group Financial Services, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Nova Scotia Securities Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Violation of S.31 and 39 of Nova Scotia Securities Act.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Settlement.  Administrative Penalty of $25,000 and costs.

ENTITYNAME: Investors Group Financial Services, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: New Brunswick Securities Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Breach of Securities Act - Trading in securities without registration.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Civil and Administrative penalties and costs in the amount of $68,200.

ENTITYNAME: Putnam Investment Management, LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Commonwealth of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Charges filed of securities fraud alleging that Putnam: (1) failed to provide adequate mutual fund prospectus disclosure relating to 'market timing', (2) failed to stop market timing activities of certain shareholders, (3) permitted Putnam investments professionals to engage in market timing for their personal accounts in mutual funds they managed, (4) failed to stop the above actions, and (5) failed to disclose the above actions.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Remedial Undertakings.  Monetary fine of $50,000,000.00, censure, disgorgement and restitution.

ENTITYNAME: Putnam Retail Management Limited Partnership
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD Office of Disciplinary Affairs
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: NASD alleged that Putnam violated NASD conduct rules 2830(L)5, 2820(G)4 and 2110 by paying for or reimbursing guest meals and ground transportation expenses during the period of 2001 to 2004, and providing and paying for entertainment, at two training & educational meetings. Also, it was alleged that Putnam violated Rules 3010 and 2110 by failing to properly supervise its non-cash compensation spending by failing to enforce its policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the NASD's non-cash compensation rules.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Acceptance, waiver & consent including censure & fine of $175,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: Randy Paul Siller, Registered Representative for New York Life
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: New York Insurance Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Mr. Siller unlawfully shared, with an unappointed agent, commissions obtained from selling four life insurance policies issued by one issuer.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: $2,500 fine imposed on Mr. Siller.

ENTITYNAME: Jerry Wesley Snyder, Registered Representative
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Ohio Division of Securities
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Ohio Division of Securities issued a Cease and Desist Order against Mr. Snyder prohibiting the sale of unregistered securities.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Mr. Snyder agreed to without admitting liability.

ENTITYNAME: Oswald Robert Donaldson, Registered Representative
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: California Department of Corporations
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: A regulatory action was initiated alleging that Mr. Donaldson took part in unlicensed activity by acting as a broker-dealer in the offer and sales of net operating interest of a corporation in the business of gold mining.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A Cease and Desist Order was issued by the Department.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Insurance Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LNL allegedly conducted variable contract business while improperly licensed.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The proceeding was closed on December 14, 1995 with the payment of a $100,000 fine by Lincoln.

ENTITYNAME: CIGNA Financial Advisors (CFA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Connecticut Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Connecticut Insurance Commissioner found CFA not appropriately licensed with respect to its financial planning activities.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: CFA agreed to voluntarily cease and desist in order to settle the matter and applied for a license for Certified Insurance Consultant.

ENTITYNAME: CIGNA Financial Advisors (CFA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Arkansas
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The dealer registration of CFA was suspended for failure to designate a principal in the State of Arkansas.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Upon designating a principal, the registration was reinstated effective July 22, 1986.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Connecticut Insurance Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Connecticut alleged that LNL used advertising materials that did not meet statutory requirements, accepted business from unappointed agents, and paid commissions to unlicensed corporations.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LNL paid a $9,000 fine on July 29, 1996.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (LNL)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Kentucky Insurance Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Kentucky alleged several violations including use of non-approved policy forms and filings, accepting business from non-licensed producers, etc.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LNL paid a $49,950 fine on October 8, 1996.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (LNL)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Maryland Insurance Administration
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The allegation was that LNL used variable life advertising prior to submitting it to the Maryland Insurance Administration in violation of CO MAR 31.09.02.03.(E).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LNL paid a $2,500 fine on January 31, 2000.

ENTITYNAME: Levi Britian Edgecombe, Registered Representative for KMS Financial Services, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: NASD alleged that Mr. Edgecombe had engaged in 'selling away' by accepting finders fees for loans made to EMF Corporation.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Mr. Edgecombe was fined $4,500 and was suspended in any capacity for five business days.  He was permitted to resign from KMS.

ENTITYNAME: Edgar Ernst Shirley, Registered Representative of CIGNA Financial Advisors
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Rhode Island Department of Business
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Rhode Island alleged that Mr. Shirley had not completed sufficient courses to satisfy Rhode Island's requirements for continuing education for 1996.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Mr. Shirley was fined $1,400 and was required to make up continuing education credit prior to expiration of license renewal period on December 31, 1998.

ENTITYNAME: Edgar Ernst Shirley, Registered Representative of Lincoln Financial Advisors
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Rhode Island Department of Business
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Mr. Shirley's license was suspended from August 21, 1999 until September 4, 1999 because he failed to provide documentation of completion of courses for continuing education requirements.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On October 19, 1999, the Continuing Education Advisory Board advised that Mr. Shirley was in compliance.

ENTITYNAME: Benjamin Lochard Hartley, Jr., Registered Representative
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of California (Commissioner of the California Department of Corporation)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The California Commissioner found that Hartley offered securities for sale that were not qualified by the Commissioner nor exempt from qualification.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Mr. Hartley agreed to pay into a Court Approved Trust Fund the amount of $1,350.

ENTITYNAME: Lincoln Financial Advisors (LFA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Securities Division of Nevada
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LFA received a notice from the Securities Division of Nevada of a $5,000 civil penalty for not properly registering a branch location in the State of Nevada.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LFA paid the $5,000 fine.

ENTITYNAME: Lincoln Financial Advisors (LFA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Connecticut Department of Banking
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Connecticut Department of Banking alleged that LFA failed to give affected clients prior written notice that a particular office had closed nor did it advise affected clients of the procedure for maintaining or transferring accounts.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On February 14, 2005, LFA entered into a Stipulation and Consent Order with Connecticut, paid a $1,500 administrative fine, and mailed required documents to affected customers.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (LNL)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Nevada Division of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Nevada levied a fine against LNL for failure to file its annual certification of advertisement report by the due date of December 31, 2004.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On November 14, 2005, The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company ('LNL'), an affiliate of the Registrant, signed and submitted to the Nevada Division of Insurance a 'Consent to Fine.' LNL paid the $500 fine on November 15, 2005.

ENTITYNAME: Lincoln Financial Advisors (LFA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: North Dakota Securities Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: A civil penalty was imposed on LFA because in March of 2001, LFA conducted four securities transactions in North Dakota. The agent involved was not registered in North Dakota at the time of the transactions.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On October 9, 2006, LFA paid a $4,000 civil penalty to the North Dakota Securities Department.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (LNL)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: The Pennsylvania Insurance Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Pennsylvania alleged that LNL: 1. failed to use delivery receipts, 2. failed to use life insurance cost disclosure documents, 3. failed to label life illustrations as 'revised' where required, and 4. other regulatory issues.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On December 4, 2006, a signed consent order was provided to LNL by Pennsylvania.  LNL sent a check for $80,000 to Pennsylvania on December 21, 2006.

ENTITYNAME: John Tracy Daley, Registered Representative
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Pennsylvania Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Mr. Daley was accused of misrepresenting the terms and conditions of insurance policies and failure to disclose other relevant information to clients.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Mr. Daley was ordered to cease and desist from engaging in the activities described above and was ordered to pay a civil penalty of $500 to the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

ENTITYNAME: Lincoln Financial Advisors (LFA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Rhode Island Securities Division
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Rhode Island Securities Division found LFA in violation of its securities laws because LFA employed two investment adviser representatives who were not properly licensed.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On March 16, 2007, the Rhode Island Securities Division and LFA entered into a Consent Agreement and LFA paid an Administrative Penalty of $5,000.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (Lincoln)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: The Ohio Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Individual Life internal and external replaced policies and procedures were not always consistently followed.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Lincoln signed a Consent Order on March 1, 2007 and agreed to pay an administrative fine of $30,000.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (Lincoln)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: North Carolina Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: During a market conduct exam of Lincoln, North Carolina found that Lincoln failed to comply with statutory requirements relative to underwriting.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A voluntary settlement was signed on March 22, 2007, and Lincoln agreed to pay a monetary assessment of $25,393.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (LNL)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Arizona Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Department of Insurance found that LNL allegedly violated several codes associated with annuity application forms.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Lincoln signed a Consent Order on October 5, 2007 and agreed to pay a fine of $45,000 to the Director for deposit in the State General Fund.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (LNL)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Colorado Division of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Division of Insurance found that LNL failed to respond to a complaint in a timely manner and to provide the requested documentation for the complaint.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Lincoln paid penalty of $1,000 on October 15, 2007.

ENTITYNAME: Richard A. Daniels, Registered Principal of PAS Securities, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Mr. Daniels was barred from association with any broker, dealer, municipal securities dealer, investment adviser or investment company.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Barred from the securities industry.

ENTITYNAME: Michael Wayne Proctor, Registered Representative for CIGNA Financial Advisors, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: A regulatory action was initiated that alleged Mr. Proctor participated in private securities transactions without prior approval of his broker-dealer.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The NASD handed down a censure and a fine in the amount of $5,000.  Mr. Proctor was also placed under special supervision for one year.

ENTITYNAME: Thomas Grayson Easterling, Jr.; Gregory B. O'Quin; and Charles Prince, Registered Repre...
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD New Orleans District Office (CO5910053)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: An investigation was initiated by the NASD regarding several registered representatives regarding questions raised from a random SEC audit which resulted in deficiencies with respect to closely held stock and registered investment adviser activities.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The NASD issued a censure and a monetary fine in the amount of $15,000 assessed jointly and severally on the three representatives. In addition, all three men agreed to requalify as general securities representatives by taking the Series 7 exam again.

ENTITYNAME: Larry Leon Steiner, Registered Representative of Connecticut General
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD Kansas City Office
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: A regulatory action was filed by the NASD alleging that Mr. Steiner sold unapproved securities to clients.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Mr. Steiner was censured and paid fines in the amount of $5,000.

ENTITYNAME: Stewart John Viets, Registered Representative of CIGNA Securities, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Plaintiffs alleged that Mr. Viets used their funds to engage in high risk investments which were inappropriate.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The claim was settled for an undisclosed amount to avoid the expense and burden of litigation and not as an admission of liability.

ENTITYNAME: Donald Sterling Hannahs, Registered Representative for CIGNA Financial Advisors, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: A regulatory action was filed with the NASD alleging that Mr. Hannahs made an inappropriate recommendation to the client, Polytemp Corp. Profit Sharing Plan and Trust to divest $100,000 of interest from Fidelity Magellan Fund.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The case was settled for $45,000.

ENTITYNAME: Franklin Keith Goldstein, Registered Representative of Lincoln Financial Advisors Corp.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: An arbitration claims was filed by a client alleging that Mr. Goldstein made inappropriate investments and alleged damages of $12,000.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A settlement of $6,300 was reached with no admission of guilt by Mr. Goldstein.

ENTITYNAME: Bronson Cooper Jacoway, Jr., Registered Representative of CIGNA Securities, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: In three separate actions, Mr. Jacoway was accused of various violations of securities rules and regulations including a breach of fiduciary duty, fraud, etc.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: In all three cases, a settlement agreement was entered into to avoid the expense and burden of litigation not as an admission of guilt or liability.

ENTITYNAME: Michael Wayne Proctor, Registered Representative for CIGNA Financial Advisors, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: A regulatory action was initiated that alleged Mr. Proctor participated in private securities transactions without prior approval of his broker-dealer.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The NASD handed down a censure and a fine in the amount of $5,000.  Mr. Proctor was also placed under special supervision for one year.

ENTITYNAME: Ernst Charles Edward Ruppert, III, Registered Representative for Royal Alliance
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: An arbitration claim was filed alleging that Mr. Ruppert sold inappropriate limited partnerships to a client and as a result, the client suffered approximately $46,000 in losses.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A settlement of $39,000 was reached and all charges against Mr. Ruppert were dropped.

ENTITYNAME: Thomas Grayson Easterling, Jr.; Gregory B. O'Quin; and Charles Prince, Registered Repre...
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD New Orleans District Office (CO5910053)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: An investigation was initiated by the NASD regarding several registered representatives regarding questions raised from a random SEC audit which resulted in deficiencies with respect to closely held stock and registered investment adviser activities.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The NASD issued a censure and a monetary fine in the amount of $15,000 assessed jointly and severally on the three representatives. In addition, all three men agreed to requalify as general securities representatives by taking the Series 7 exam again.

ENTITYNAME: Larry Leon Steiner, Registered Representative of Connecticut General
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD Kansas City Office
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: A regulatory action was filed by the NASD alleging that Mr. Steiner sold unapproved securities to clients.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Mr. Steiner was censured and paid fines in the amount of $5,000.

ENTITYNAME: Lincoln Financial Advisors (LFA)
ACTIONTITLE: Letter of Acceptance, Waiver and Consent
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On July 1, 2005, the NASD notified LFA of its acceptance of a Letter of Acceptance, Waiver and Consent. The Letter noted violations of NASD Rules 2110 and 3070 and maintenance of adequate written supervisory procedures.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LFA filed all the requisite disclosures under NASD Rules 2110 and 3070 and prepared written supervisory procedures in compliance with Rule 3070(c). LFA signed the Letter of Acceptance, Waiver and Consent (the 'Letter') and agreed to pay any fines.

ENTITYNAME: Lincoln Financial Advisors (LFA)
ACTIONTITLE: Letter of Acceptance, Waiver and Consent
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The NASD alleged that LFA violated NASD Rules in connection with an agreement between mutual fund complexes and LFA's clearing firms by receiving directed brokerage commission payments.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On August 5, 2005, LFA submitted to the NASD a Letter of Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, and paid a $950,000 fine on August 29, 2005.

ENTITYNAME: Richard A. Daniels, Registered Principal of PAS Securities, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Mr. Daniels pled guilty to two counts of using the mail in interstate commerce to sell unregistered securities.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: He was fined $5,000 and placed on probation for five years.

ENTITYNAME: Delaware Service Company, Inc. (DSC)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: SEC
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC found that DSC violated Sections 19(A) and 34(B).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On September 18, 2006, Delaware Service Company, Inc. paid a $425,000 fine to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ENTITYNAME: Edward Csibi, Registered Representative
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Sometime prior to 1991, a hearing was held at the NASD Cleveland, Ohio office at which time Mr. Csibi was barred for life from association with an NASD member.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Sometime prior to 1991, a hearing was held at the NASD Cleveland, Ohio office at which time Mr. Csibi was barred for life from association with an NASD member.

ENTITYNAME: Thomas Ralph Hardon, Registered Representative for LNC Equity Sales Corporation
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD District No. 5
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The NASD alleged that Mr. Hardon violated the NASD's Rules of Fair Practice when he purchased 650 shares of Radiation Care, Inc. through another NASD member without prior approval from his broker dealer.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The NASD imposed a censure, and fined Mr. Hardon $2,500.

ENTITYNAME: Richard A. Daniels, Registered Principal of PAS Securities, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Mr. Daniels was enjoined from further violations of certain Sections of the Securities Act and the Securities Exchange Act.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Permanent injunction.

ENTITYNAME: Delaware Service Company, Inc. (DSC)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: SEC
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC found that DSC violated Sections 19(A) and 34(B).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On September 18, 2006, Delaware Service Company, Inc. paid a $425,000 fine to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ENTITYNAME: CIGNA Financial Adivsors (CFA)

ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The dealer registration of CFA was suspended for failure to designate a principal in the State of Arkansas.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Upon designating a principal, the registration was reinstated effective July 22, 1986.

ENTITYNAME: John Tracy Daley, Registered Representative
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Pennsylvania Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Mr. Daley was accused of misrepresenting the terms and conditions of insurance policies and failure to disclose other relevant information to clients.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Mr. Daley was ordered to cease and desist from engaging in the activities described above and was ordered to pay a civil penalty of $500 to the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

ENTITYNAME: CIGNA Financial Advisors (CFA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Connecticut Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Connecticut Insurance Commissioner found CFA not appropriately licensed with repect to its financial planning activities.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: CFA agreed to voluntarily cease and desist in order to settle the matter and applied for a license for Certified Insurance Consultant.

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (Lincoln)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: The Ohio Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Individual life internal and external replacement policies and procedures were not always consistently followed.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Lincoln signed a Consent Order on March 1, 2007 and agreed to pay an administrative fine of $30,000.

ENTITYNAME: Lincoln Independent Limited ('LIL'), an indirect subsidiary of Lincoln National Corporation
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Personal Investment Authority ('RIA'), a United Kingdom SRO
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The PIA alleged that LIL failed to take all reasonable steps to carry out its pension review in accordance with PIA standards and failed to adequately monitor the conduct of its review with a view of ensuring compliance with its procedures and its own com
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The proceedings was closed on July 8, 1997 with payment of LIL of a 75,000 pound fine and 10,000 pounds in additional costs.

ENTITYNAME: Oswald Robert Donaldson, Registered Representative
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: California Department of Corporations
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: A regulatory action was initiated alleging that Mr. Donaldson took part in unlicensed activity by acting as a broker-dealer in the offer and sales of net operating interest of a corporation in the business of gold mining.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A Cease and Desist Order was issued by the Department.

ENTITYNAME: CIGNA Financial Advisors (CFA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Connecticut Department of Insurance

ENTITYNAME: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company (LNL)

COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Connecticut Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Connecticut Insurance Commissioner found CFA not appropriately licensed with respect to its financial planning activities.

ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Mr. Juras did not renew his Michigan securities license because he was no longer involved in securities sales.

ENTITYNAME: Ronald Joseph Maxfield, Registered Representative for LNC Equity Sales Corporation
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Securities Division

ENTITYNAME: Computershare Trust Company of Canada, Inc.
ACTIONTITLE: In the Matter of Computershare Trust Company of Canada Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Without admitting or denying the findings, on April 18, 2006 Computershare Trust Company of Canada, Inc. ('CTCC'), agreed to settle an administrative action by the SEC in which it was ordered to cease-and-desist from violations of Sections 15(b) and 17A(c) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. See, In the Matter of Computershare Trust Company of Canada Inc., Administrative Proceeding 3-12265, Securities Exchange Act Release No. 53668 (April 18, 2006). The proceedings related to CTCC's failure to register with the SEC as a U.S. transfer agent and a U.S. broker-dealer. As part of the settlement, CTCC was ordered to disgorge profits, including prejudgment interest, of $601,868.71 attributable to certain of its services associated with the U.S. during the period from June 2000 to April 2004 when it became registered as a U.S. Transfer Agent, as well as a fine in the amount of $500,000. At the same time, the SEC issued a conditional exemption to permit CTCC and its affiliate, Computershare Investor Services, LLC, to continue to provide plan services to U.S. residents without registering as a U.S. broker-dealer in accordance with Section 15(b). Exchange Act Release No. 53667 (April 18, 2006).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See Above.

ENTITYNAME: Computershare Securities Corporation
ACTIONTITLE: Letter of Acceptance, Waiver, and Consent (AWC)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: National Association of Securities Dealers Regulation, Inc.
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Computershare Securities Corporation (CRD #107023, Chicago, Illinois) submitted a Letter of Acceptance, Waiver and Consent in which the firm was censured and fined $60,000. Without admitting or denying the findings, the firm consented to the described sanctions and to the entry of findings that it executed securities transactions while failing to maintain its minimum required net capital. The findings stated that the firm failed to comply with SEC Rule 17a-3(a) in that it prepared inaccurate trial balances and net capital computations for numerous months. The findings also stated that the firm failed to comply with SEC Rule 17a-5 in that it filed inaccurate NASD Financial Operational Combined Uniform Single (FOCUS) Part IIA Reports for several months. (NASD Case #E8A2005005301)
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See Above.

ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that The Bank of New York Mellon (formerly, The Bank of New York, 'BNY') failed as a transfer agent to exercise reasonable care to ascertain the correct addresses of lost security holders and escheated assets belonging to those security holders to various states. ENTITYNAME: CIBC Mellon Trust Company
ACTIONTITLE: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission v. CIBC Mellon Trust Company
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ('SEC')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: CIBC Mellon Trust Company ('CMTC'), a transfer agent that is an affiliate of Registrant by virtue of Mellon Canada Holding Company's 50 percent interest in the joint venture, submitted a Consent to Entry of Judgment (the 'Consent') which was presented by the SEC in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia (the 'Court) on February 16, 2005. In the Consent, and solely for the purpose of the injunctive action and any other proceedings arising out of the SEC's investigation brought by or on behalf of the SEC or to which the SEC is a party, CMTC consented to the entry of Final Judgment as to Defendant CMTC )the 'Final Judgment') without admitting or denying the matters set forth therein (other than those relating to the jurisdiction of the Court and the subject matter of the action). The Final Judgment, entered on February 24, 2005, resolved the allegations that CMTC had failed to register as a transfer agent with the SEC, that it had issued 'legend free' stock certificates of a company whose shares were not registered with the SEC, that one of its managers had accepted payments of stock from that company's officers to issue the certificates, and that it had acted as an unregistered broker or dealer in connection with its stock plan administration business. CMTC was permanently enjoined from prescribed violations of Securities Act Section 5, Exchange Act Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5, Exchange Act Section 15(a), Exchange Act Section 17A(c)(1), and from aiding and abetting future violations of Exchange Act Section 10(b) or Rule 10b-5. CMTC also agreed to pay a civil monetary penalty of $5 million and disgorgement of $889,773 and prejudgment interest of $140,270. Payment was made on March 4, 2005. CMTC also consented, without admitting or denying the SEC complaint allegations, to the entry of an SEC administrative order based on the Final Judgment on March 2, 2005 (the 'Order'). Pursuant to the Order, CMTC was censured and agreed to an undertaking to engage an independent consultant to review its relevant businesses and procedures. This matter responds to items 10(b)(1) and 10(c)(2).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Entry of Judgment on consent. See item (v) above for detail.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Attorney offices for the EDNY and SDNY
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Bank Of New York Mellon (formerly, The Bank of New York, the 'Bank'), an affiliate of the registrant, entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorneys offices for the Eastern and Southern Districts of New York ('EDNY' and 'SDNY'). The respective EDNY and SDNY investigations related to actions by Bank employees that facilitated a fraudulent scheme conducted by RW Professional Leasing Services Corp., a former customer of one of the Bank's Long Island branch offices, and certain funds transfer activities to and from Russia from 1996 to1999. Among other things, the non-prosecution agreement outlines a series of measures, many of which already are completed and others that are well underway, to enhance the Bank's procedures for monitoring and reporting suspicious activity. The Bank has agreed to pay restitution and forfeiture totaling $38 million, all of which has been previously reserved. The agreement, which has a term of three years, provides for the Bank to retain an independent examiner to review the enhanced procedures and report to the government on a periodic basis.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10 (d) (2) (v) above

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that from at least January 1, 2003 through June 30, 2004, in connection with certain auctions, The Bank of New York Mellon (formerly, The Bank of New York, 'BNY') accepted initial or revised bids after submission deadlines and allowed broker-dealers to intervene in auctions. In certain instances, this conduct also affected the rate paid on the auction rate securities. As a result, BNY caused violations of section 17(a)(2) of the Securities Act. BNY was required to make certain disclosures regarding its material auction practices and procedures; and not later than 6 months after the date of this order, unless otherwise extended by the Staff of the Commission for good cause shown, have its CEO or general counsel certify in writing to the Staff of the Commission that BNY has implemented procedures. In addition BNY paid a monetary settlement in the amount of $750,000.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(c)(2)(v) above

ENTITYNAME: Dreyfus Service Organization, Inc.
ACTIONTITLE: Proceeding by the Commissioner of Banking and Ins. State of NJ Ref. No. 8059711
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, Trenton, New Jersey
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: It was alleged that Dreyfus Service Organization ('DSO') between June 2002 and November 2002 'caused, permitted or was otherwise responsible for allowing the employee to solicit and write eight New Jersey annuity contracts without the benefit of a current license.' DSO had an employee with a non-resident NJ insurance license which had expired and was later reinstated. The sales were made during the period when the employee's license was inactive, although DSO had reason to believe the license was, in fact, active. Without admitting or denying any violation of the insurance statutes or regulations or any wrongdoing, DSO consented to an administrative sanction in the amount of $4,000.00 to fully and completely resolve the matter.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(d)(4)(v) above.

ENTITYNAME: ALPS Mutual Fund Services, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: National Association of Securities Dealers
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: It was alleged on July 31st, August 29th, September 30th, and November 30, 1997 that ALPS Mutual Fund Services conducted securities business while failing to maintain minimum net capital requirements under SEC Rule 15c3-1 and NASD Rule 2110.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: ALPS agreed to the following actions: (1) CFO obtain a Series 28 License, (2) a new attorney was hired (3) a new CPA hired (4) a new net capital procedures and (5) Re-education for ALPS Principals. ALPS agreed to censure & $5k fine.
